fried rice.author: Eric L.
fried rice.review: This place is B-E-S-T and I keep coming back.  The Garlic Noodle and Roast Crab are to die for.  The best combination that you'll ever have guaranteed.  The special seasoning on the crab is like crack too.  Super good!  I also like the Seafood Fried Rice cause they put some real crab in it, but next time I might just get 2 orders of the Garlic Noodle.  It's that good!!! Oh yeah, did I mention that the service is awesome too?!

excerpts: The red snapper was perfect  and the fried rice with chicken was moist and delicious.
For dessert we shared the creme brûlée cheesecake, fried banana and orange  sorbet which tasted like a delicious creamsicle.
The service was as great as the food.
Our server was attentive and efficient, paying attention to detail.
fried rice.author: Kim S.
fried rice.review:
Great great great MEAL!!!!! From start to finish the service and food were awesome. We saw the restaurant on the travel channel and couldn't wait to taste the garlic noodles. Vacationing from New Jersey this was one of the first dinner reservations we made. We started with the mango salad and the Vietnamese salad. Both were flavorful and fresh. We shared entrees between the 8 of us. The favorite was the garlic noodles. They were extremely garlicky with a slight bite. We also had the lemongrass chicken which was full of flavor and slightly spicy. The red snapper was perfect  and the fried rice with chicken was moist and delicious.  For dessert we shared the creme brûlée cheesecake, fried banana and orange  sorbet which tasted like a delicious creamsicle. 
The service was as great as the food. Our server was attentive and efficient, paying attention to detail. We would highly recommend this restaurant and wish we could bring the garlic noodles to the east coast.

excerpts: Along with some shrimp fried rice.
So they bring the shrimp fried rice out.....and 2 other plates of rice.

Then the waiter comes out and asks how our food is,I'm looking around and say great, I'm just waiting for my Seafood combination and that's when he drops the bomb telling me the plate full of rice is the combo plate... shut my mouth!!
I told him the fried rice and the combo plate looked identical to one another.
I was truly blown away.
I'm thinking like Red Lobster or some other seafood restaurant where you can truly see the scallops, prawns in your dish....
what they call a Seafood Combo are tiny pieces of prawns, crab meat and scallops....microscopic sizes.
I just couldn't believe it.
All the way from Concord for this.....basically a bowl rice.
I'm still speechless.
I'm just assuming those that come here don't really cook their own crab (less thank 15min folks and damn sure less tha $60 per crab).
Needless to say we were all disappointed and figured the noodles would make up for it...
but nope they didn't.
We definitely will not be venturing back to this spot.
Maybe this is why it took us 10+ years to go back.
I would post a picture but the shrimp fried rice and the combo plate looked the same.
UUgghh :( Swindled out of $130 and no free refills for lemonade....feeling like Ice Cube...no vaseline
fried rice.author: Shan C.
fried rice.review: So after 10+long years the family and I ventured out to this restaurant tonight. I kept raving to my boyfriend from Detroit about the noodles. So we get there and get seated right away cool...but then I had to go to the bathroom and mind you this restaurant closes down to reopen at 5pm for dinner...went inside and someone used the bathroom and didn't flush- ugh! Okay I can kind of over look this seeing that the bathroom wasn't dirty and smelled decent. But to know that the bathroom wasn't refreshed before the dinner shift did leave an unsettling feeling. So I go back to my seat and we go over the menu and order. I wanted to order the crab but when you yourself buy and cook crab and see the prices they were charging you scratch your head and wonder why are is the price so high? $60 for a whole crab??? Really when I can go to Safeway, luckys or Winco and buy and whole crab $4.99 - $6.99... get the heck out of here with this. So I settled for what they call the Seafood combination with scallops, prawns and crabmeat. Along with some shrimp fried rice. So they bring the shrimp fried rice out.....and 2 other plates of rice. Then the waiter comes out and asks how our food is,I'm looking around and say great, I'm just waiting for my Seafood combination and that's when he drops the bomb telling me the plate full of rice is the combo plate... shut my mouth!! I told him the fried rice and the combo plate looked identical to one another. I was truly blown away. I'm thinking like Red Lobster or some other seafood restaurant where you can truly see the scallops, prawns in your dish....what they call a Seafood Combo are tiny pieces of prawns, crab meat and scallops....microscopic sizes. I just couldn't believe it. All the way from Concord for this.....basically a bowl rice. I'm still speechless. I'm just assuming those that come here don't really cook their own crab (less thank 15min folks and damn sure less tha $60 per crab). Needless to say we were all disappointed and figured the noodles would make up for it...but nope they didn't. We definitely will not be venturing back to this spot. Maybe this is why it took us 10+ years to go back. I would post a picture but the shrimp fried rice and the combo plate looked the same. UUgghh :( Swindled out of $130 and no free refills for lemonade....feeling like Ice Cube...no vaseline

excerpts: Then, we went garlic crazy and ordered garlic fried rice.
fried rice.author: Truc N.
fried rice.review:
On the night of the full moon, we ventured out of the city. We drove towards the setting sun, passing many other good lookin' eateries, promised a crab coma experience...

We entered a simple door. The garlic pervaded everything. It was the kind that made you hungry, newly fried garlic that makes your mouth water. All around, people sat with plastic bibs! The group of diners to my left were happily passing around the famous noodles. The couple in front of me finished ordering and started to tie back their hair. An odd thing to do, but soon I'd fully understand.

I glanced down at the menu and inhaled the garlic permeating the air, agreeing it was worth the trip from downtown to the other side to eat at Thanh Long. My hometown, Nha Trang, was even labeled on the menu cover. :-) Then, the waiters tied a bib on me and walked away with a knowing look. We started with the salmon carpaccio and the shrimp toast. The salmon was sliced thinly enough to hold full flavor and the citrus hit was perfect. The shrimp toast was pillow goodness. The topping reminded me of the shrimp paste around sugar cane.

Then the garlic noodles! So good! Best when eaten hot, so get it on your plate then into your belly fast. The noodles were a nice chewy texture and a subtle garlic flavor that was nothing as powerful as its garlic aroma. Then again, you're hit with garlic the moment you walk in.

Then...THE CRAB! Some of the best Dungeoness crab I've ever eaten. My table ordered the roasted crab and tamarind crab. Very different. Very satisfying. I paused for a split second to be thankful all my hair was already tied up. No one at my table ate their crab carapaces, so this Vietnamese gal was in heaven with five all to herself! Then, we went garlic crazy and ordered garlic fried rice. The tamarind crab went great with it.

After all this, I had a disappointing fried banana. Others had the orange sherbet and the molten lava cake and enjoyed their desserts. My fried banana had no hint of a sugar finish...brown, white, nor palm. The banana was no where near sweet enough to carry it. 

But, I went for the crab, not the dessert. So, high ratings from me.

excerpts: The only dish we like was the fried rice.
fried rice.author: Janita s.
fried rice.review: It used to be a lot better in both their food and service.  The crab was bland and soggy.   The mix vegetable was a joke.   The garlic noodles was oily and small portion for its price.  The waiter was pushy and two faced.   The only dish we like was the fried rice.

excerpts: Also ordered Fried Rice with shrimp, scallops and crab meat.
All dishes were delicious.
Sure it is expensive but every once in a while you need to splurge and this is worth it.
Crab was very meaty, moist and seasoned well.
Took home 1/2 order of the fried rice and whole order of garlic noodles.
fried rice.author: Leann S.
fried rice.review:
First of all reservations are recommended this is a busy place.  Valet parking is $12.00 but this is a very residential area and parking is a premium.  I am currently in a wheel chair and the staff found me a place to wait out of the way  that made the time pass more pleasantly as I was not looking at everyone's belt buckle.

Nice bar menu and my husband had the Asian Martini that was very good.

Ordered "Secret Kitchen" items of baked crab ($53.00), Jumbo black tiger prawns with garlic noodles and order of Garlic Noodles.  Also ordered Fried Rice with shrimp, scallops and crab meat.  All dishes were delicious. Sure it is expensive but every once in a while you need to splurge and this is worth it.  Crab was very meaty, moist and seasoned well.  Prawns were great.

Took home 1/2 order of the fried rice and whole order of garlic noodles.  Waiter even provided suggestions on how to reheat in the microwave.

Wait staff and management are super.  Always checking back on you and cleaning away shell often.  Very hot towel is provided at end of meal and it was very nice. 

We will return and suggest this to others to tryl

excerpts: The sides are a la carte, so we also ordered the garlic noodles, shrimp fried rice, garlic toast and the seasonal vegetable sauté to go with our crab.
fried rice.author: Tashi L.
fried rice.review:
As a Frisco native, Thanh Long has been a long-time favorite of mine for as long as I can remember. I had the pleasure of celebrating my birthday here on 5/26/15 and I am pleased to say that even though it had been over a decade since my last visit, the service and food have not changed! This family-owned and operated gem of a place has some of the best seafood (crab, prawns and garlic noodles - yes, please!) in the city.
 
I had an 8:15 p.m. reservation for a party of 10 (close friends and family). If you're familiar with the city, then you know this place is located allllll the way in the Avenues, so it can take up to an hour to get to in rush hour traffic. I arrived extremely late to find everyone in my party seated and waiting for me, which I appreciated, as the restaurant was pretty full. They could've bumped my table or refused to seat my guests, but they did not. Kudos for that.
 
Since it had been awhile, I wanted some of everything on the menu and my guests thankfully obliged me. We ordered several whole roast Dungeness crabs in their special garlic seasoning. I rarely order Dungeness crab anywhere else because not everyone cleans and cooks it properly, but at Thanh Long, it is a MUST. It was delicious, just like I remembered! It's also very filling with everything else. I ended up splitting half of mine with my godsister. The sides are a la carte, so we also ordered the garlic noodles, shrimp fried rice, garlic toast and the seasonal vegetable sauté to go with our crab. My mom ordered her usual tiger prawns over garlic noodles. (The four prawns come butterflied over the noodles). She refused to let me have a taste, so I assume it was as good as she remembered, too. For those who may not like crab or shrimp like one of my friends, the mango salad is recommended - without the scallops or shrimps, of course. As far as libations go, they have a full bar and decent cocktails. I only had Goose on the rocks with two limes, so I can't comment on the other drinks.
 
If you don't like garlic, this is not the place for you. And if you are price conscious, this is not the place for you LOL! They do accept walk-ins depending on how busy they are. The place is not huge, so just phone ahead and reserve whenever possible. Street parking is available, but the surrounding area is residential so it may be hard to come by. Valet is $12. Not bad for San Francisco.
 
For me, the only downside is living out-of-state, but I would recommend this place for special occasions.

We loved the crispy fried rice paper rolls, the salt and pepper calamari was a little overdone for our taste.
We then put on our bibs and started cracking the Dungeness crab.
We loved the crispy fried rice paper rolls, the salt and pepper calamari was a little overdone for our taste.
We then put on our bibs and started cracking the Dungeness crab.
OMG - this was really good and then dug into the garlic noodles and tried the colossal tiger prawns.

fried rice.review: I've been told by numerous parties to come and visit this place. Since I live in the San Jose area, it's not easy to go in just for dinner.  Today was the day since we had plans to be in SF for the day.  I made a reservation and showed up and was ready to go.  We ordered the crispy fried rice paper rolls, the salt and pepper calamari, the roasted Dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the garlic noodles with the colossal tiger prawns.  We loved the crispy fried rice paper rolls, the salt and pepper calamari was a little overdone for our taste.  We then put on our bibs and started cracking the Dungeness crab.  OMG - this was really good and then dug into the garlic noodles and tried the colossal tiger prawns.  Everything was really good and now I think we'll make it a plan to come in for meals in SF more often.

excerpts: Fried rice (6/5)
: if there was one dish that stood out from all of them, it was this dish.
A simple, (even unimpressive) looking fried rice dish that just blew people away with its wok-seared taste and awesome flavors.
Fried rice, yes.
But extraordinary?
fried rice.author: Glenn H.
fried rice.review:
4.5 stars. Minus a half a star for the value of some of the items but overall a terrific night out.

This is a prize of a place. Comfortable setting, great service, excellent quality food and, while maybe spend-y, is worth a look.

For our New Years eve dinner there we four had reservations (needed given the size of the place) at 8 PM. We started the night with two appetizers:

1. Tempura Style Coconut Prawns (3/5). These were not so much the Japanese style tempura (corn starch batter) that you might have had but more coconut shaving encrusted large prawns. There were 5 and were good but, if I had to go again, not a must have.

2. Dungeness Crab Puffs (4/5). These were 6, small, perfectly deep fried, wonton-skin wrapped pillows of Dungeness crab filling that were so much better than the typical Crab Rangoon's that you might have had elsewhere. They came with two dipping sauces, the better one was the sweet mustard. This was a nice, if pricey, treat and a good start to the entrees. 

Four entrees:

1. Roasted Crab (4/5): this smelled wonderful as it came out and was a large, already cut up Dungeness crab, with the carapace shell. It was meaty and perfectly done with the garlic sauce. Really glad we tried this. I like crab but it isn't a must have for me. My table-mates really like it. Market price was almost $40 each.

2. Shaken Beef (5/5): very tender tasty cubes of beef (not well done, if that's important to you) that was marinated in a lightly sweet sauce, served with potato cubes that had also been marinated in the same dark sauce and grilled; all of this served over tender bay greens. Delicious! Everyone liked this dish. The Rice and Roll's Hunan Grilled Butter Beef was very comparable (and less expensive) than this dish but this was still a winning dish. And I need to mention the tender-crisp cuts of sweet Vidalia (that's my guess) onions that were served with this dish, they were great in their own right and really added dimension to the beef.

3. Seafood Combination (Scallops, prawns, Dungeness crab) Fried rice (6/5): if there was one dish that stood out from all of them, it was this dish. A simple, (even unimpressive) looking fried rice dish that just blew people away with its wok-seared taste and awesome flavors. Fried rice, yes. But extraordinary? For a mere $16 Absolutely!

4. Colossal Royal Tiger Prawns (5/5): 4 large butterflied and perfectly grilled in the shell prawns that were served over a bed of their famously delicious garlic noodles. Yeah this was a splurge, at almost $10 a prawn, this was expensive but very (very) good and to be served over the deservedly vaunted garlic noodles, this was a plus. We didn't have to order the Garlic Noodles as an entree because of this, and the waiter was smart enough to understand this by ignoring our order for these Prawns PLUS a Garlic Noodle order. The prawns did have a tendency to stick to their shells, but they were perfectly done and marinated in some fantastic sauce to make them outstanding.

The Garlic noodles had the perfect consistency of Yee Noodles, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yi_mein, which gives them an extra nice bite and appear to absorb the flavors better. They are also pricey. The Garlic Noodles by themselves were $9.50 an order, which seems a bit high for lo mein noodles and garlic, but if they are Yee noodles, they would be more fairly priced. Everyone at the table loved these. 

Three deserts: 

Creme Brulee (3/5): this was an OK rendition of Creme Brulee, not bad but not up to the standards of the rest of the meal. Nothing really special.

Chocolate Lava Cake (5/5): Oh yeah! This chocolate delight was the size of a very small hockey puck served with a large scoop of vanilla ice cream over a pool of Grand Marnier & melted vanilla ice cream. It was pricey ($9) but oh so very wonderful to have that rich oozing chocolate goodness.

Fried Banana Fritters a la Mode. (5/5): 2 fritters (your choice of pineapple or banana) served with that same scoop of dense vanilla ice cream. Love, Love, Love this simple but wonderful desert.

It was almost a perfect amount of food for 4 with each of us full to the neck and almost giddy from the great food experience.

While the restaurant was crowded, it never seemed loud or noisy and the service was spot-on: unobtrusive, available, and very polite.

With tip we were at about $50 per person without drinks (which included one modestly iced tea for $2.50).

Loved it and would eagerly go again for a special occasion!
